note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Lung mass with left main-stem obstruction
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant mixed intrinsic and extrinsic airway obstruction
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy
INDICATIONS: left mainstem obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. A 7.0 ETT was placed by ansesthesia followed by OG tube to decompress the stomach. The ETT was then removed and a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the mid trachea and attached to the jet ventilator. The rigid optic was then removed and the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope. On initial bronchoscopic inspection there was mild bleeding and airway trauma noted in the distal trachea likely secondary to trauma from ETT placement. The posterior and left wall of the distal trachea had obvious submucosal tumor infiltration. The left mainstem bronchus was completely obstructed by endoluminal tumor and the tumor involved the main carina with a mild degree of tumor ingrowth into the right mainstem but without obstruction. At this point the EBUS bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope and the subcarinal mass was identified with ultrasound and 6 biopsies were performed with the 22G EBUS TBNA needle. We then directed our attention to the left maintem. Through the use of a combination of APC, rigid electrocautery, cryotherapy and forcpts we were able to slowly debulk the tumor within the left mainstem and visualize an opening into the distal left mainstem. A ultrathin bronchospe was advanced through the opening and purulent material was expressed from the distal airways from her post-obstructive pneumonia. We were able to visualize the secondary carina’s within the left upper lobe and there was no obvious tumor seen. The left lower lobe was visualized but we were unable to adequately debulk the tumor to overlying this area to confirm distal patency. Subseuqently the left mainstem bronchus was dilated with an 8-9-10 CRE balloon with approximaly 50% improvement in luminal patency in the left mainstem which allowed introduction of the therapeutic bronchoscope. At this point the infiltrating friable areas of tumor within the left mainstem, distal trachea and main carina were painted with argon plasma coagulation for hemostasis. Once we were satisfied that there was no active bleeding the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Recommendations:
Await tissue diagnosis
ASAP radiation oncology consultation for treatment of the left mainstem to attempt to prevent recurrent obstruction.
If patient develops significant hemoptysis post procedure would perform bronchoscopic intubation of the right mainstem to protect functional lung. 
If obstruction recurs despite radiation therapy will likely require repeat rigid bronchoscopy with placement of silicone Y stent.

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Lung mass with left main-stem obstruction

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Mild bleeding/trauma distal trachea. Distal trachea/left wall submucosal tumor infiltration. Left mainstem completely obstructed. Main carina involvement. Mild tumor ingrowth right mainstem.

thermal_ablation.location: Left mainstem, distal trachea, main carina

complications.other_complication_details: Mild bleeding and airway trauma noted in distal trachea likely secondary to ETT placement.

outcomes.preliminary_diagnosis: Malignant mixed intrinsic and extrinsic airway obstruction
outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Await tissue diagnosis. ASAP radiation oncology consultation. Monitor for hemoptysis.

follow_up_actions.notes: If obstruction recurs, consider Y stent

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Left mainstem completely obstructed by endoluminal tumor; 50% improvement after intervention; purulent material expressed from distal airways.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with EBUS sampling, 1-2 nodal stations
lines.selection_reason: EBUS-TBNA of Station 7 (1 station). Distinct family from 31641.
Bundled into 31641 when dilation is performed in the same segment (LMS) as tumor destruction.

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree
lines.selection_reason: Bundled into 31652 per NCCI indicator 0 (no modifier allowed).
Diagnostic bronchoscopy bundled into surgical codes 31641/31652.

financial_analysis.mppr_assumptions: Primary 31641 paid 100%. Secondary 31652 likely reduced by 50% of (Secondary - Base) logic, or standard 50% MPPR depending on payer.

per_code.summary: Primary code for tumor destruction in the left mainstem using APC, cryotherapy, and electrocautery. 31641 is preferred over 31640 when ablative energies are the dominant or co-dominant modality for 'relief of stenosis'.

documentation_evidence.snippet: Through the use of a combination of APC, rigid electrocautery, cryotherapy and forcpts we were able to slowly debulk the tumor
subcarinal mass was identified with ultrasound and 6 biopsies were performed

per_code.summary: Dropped. Balloon dilation of the LMS is bundled with tumor destruction (31641) in the same anatomic segment.

documentation_evidence.snippet: left mainstem bronchus was dilated with an 8-9-10 CRE balloon

per_code.summary: Dropped. NCCI strictly bundles therapeutic aspiration (31645) into EBUS (31652) with no unbundling allowed (Indicator 0), even though distinct pathology (pneumonia) was treated.

documentation_evidence.snippet: purulent material was expressed from the distal airways

global_comments: Rigid bronchoscopy is the method, not a separately billable CPT in this context.
General anesthesia was used; moderate sedation codes (99152/3) are not applicable.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Lung mass with right main-stem obstruction
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant intrinsic airway obstruction
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy with tumor debulking
INDICATIONS: right mainstem obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Once adequate anesthesia and muscle relaxation were achieved a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was inserted past the vocal cords and into the mid trachea and attached to the jet ventilator. The rigid optic was then removed and the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope. On initial bronchoscopic inspection, the trachea was normal without evidence of endobronchial or extrinsic obstruction. The left aspect of the carina was sharp and left sided airways were normal to at least the first sub-segmental bronchi. On the right there was near complete endobronchial tumor obstruction (95%) in the right mainstem at extending beyond the right upper lobe stump into the bronchus intermedius. Endobronchial forceps biopsies were performed in the right mainstem. After which the FIO2 was reduced to 30% and argon plasma coagulation was used to superficially burn the obstructive tumor followed by shaving of charred tumor with the tip of the flexible bronchoscope and removal of loose fragments using flexible forceps. This was repeated until eventually we were able to achieve about 85% re-canalization of the proximal right sided airways. Once the main obstruction was bypassed, in the distal bronchus intermedius there was significant submucosal tumor infiltration causing at least 80% obstruction up to the level of the right middle lobe stump. APC was used in a similar fashion to debulk resulting in about 70% re-canalization.   Anatomic distortion (bronchial kink) was seen further obstructing the right lower lobe (approximately 40%) but within the right lower lobe the airways were widely patient. Once we were satisfied that there was no active bleeding the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Recommendations:
- Transfer to PACU and then home once discharge criteria are met 
- Urgent radiation oncology consultation for treatment of the right sided airways in an attempt to prevent recurrent obstruction.

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Lung mass with right main-stem obstruction

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Trachea normal. Left airways normal. RMS 95% obstruction. BI 80% obstruction. RLL 40% obstruction (kink).

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Near complete obstruction extending beyond RUL stump. 85% recanalization achieved.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Transfer to PACU. Urgent radiation oncology consultation.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method

lines.description: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis
lines.selection_reason: Primary therapeutic intervention for central airway obstruction using APC and mechanical debulking. Highest valued code in family.
Bundled into 31641 when performed at the same anatomic site (Right Mainstem/BI). 31641 covers relief of stenosis by 'any method'.
Biopsy of the target lesion prior to destruction/excision is integral to the therapeutic procedure and generally bundled.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy is bundled when surgical bronchoscopy is performed.

per_code.summary: Selected for destruction of tumor in the Right Mainstem and Bronchus Intermedius using APC. This code is chosen over 31640 (excision) because it is higher valued and covers the 'relief of stenosis by any method', which accurately describes the combination of APC burning and mechanical shaving.

documentation_evidence.snippet: argon plasma coagulation was used to superficially burn the obstructive tumor followed by shaving of charred tumor... APC was used in a similar fashion to debulk

rules_applied.description: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled with therapeutic procedures.
Tumor destruction (31641) and excision (31640) at the same site are bundled. 31641 is the dominant code.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant central airway obstruction. 
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Intraoperative death.
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy with endobronchial debulking and balloon dilatation. 
INDICATIONS: Right mainstem endobronchial obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient’s family acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Following intravenous medications as per the record a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was inserted through the mouth into the distal trachea and advanced into the distal trachea before attaching the monsoon JET ventilator. The T180 theraputic flexible bronchoscope was insterted through the rigid bronchoscope and airway inspection was performed. The proximal and mid trachea were normal. There was tumor infiltration within the distal trachea just proximal to the main carina on the right lateral wall with slowly oozing blood visualized. That main carina was involved on the right side. The left sided aiways were normal.  The proximal right mainstem was completely obstructed with friable enbdobronchial tumor APC was used to burn and shave the tumor and flexible forceps were used for biopsy. As we slowly debulked the tumor it became clear that the involvement was extensive. Using the P90 slim bronchoscope we were able to bypass tumor using saline aliquots to stent the airway open and eventually could visualize the basilar segments of the lower lobe where persistent tumor was seen. Using a forgery balloon and the pullback method we were able to dilate the airway slightly and then using an 8,9,10 CRE balloon gently dilated the BI and RLL bronchus. While bleeding was encountered it was not brisk and was controlled with tropical TXA, epi and cold saline. While considering stent placement the patient’s blood pressure began to slowly drop despite increasing vasopressor requirement and patient went into PEA/Asystole. Code blue was called and CRP initiated. A left sided chest tube was placed and there was no gush of air concerning for PTX. Ultrasound showed no cardiac motion and no evidence of pericardial effusion. Patient received multiple doses of epinephrine and chest compressions but remained in non-shockable rhythm (asystole).  Decision was made to attempt TPA given that all other H’s and T’s were considered and not apparent. This did not have any effect. While we were confident that a right sided PTX was not present (lung completely obstructed by tumor and atelectatic) A right sided chest tube was placed to attempt to offload pressure from known pleural effusion again without response. At hat 15:10 after approximately 30 minutes of CPR the patient was declared dead. Family was notified and handled information appropriately. Medical examiner was contacted and declined case.  
Complications:  Intra-operative death (direct cause unclear)

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Proximal/mid trachea normal. Tumor infiltration distal trachea proximal to carina (right lateral). Carina involved right side. Left airways normal. RMS completely obstructed.

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Tumor infiltration distal trachea right lateral wall.
Completely obstructed with friable tumor. APC burn/shave and flexible forceps biopsy/debulking.

specimens_collected.notes: Flexible forceps used for biopsy during debulking.

complications.other_complication_details: Intraoperative death (PEA/Asystole) of unclear cause. Code blue initiated, CPR x 30 mins, TPA given, patient declared dead.

outcomes.preliminary_diagnosis: Malignant central airway obstruction, Intraoperative death
outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Medical examiner contacted and declined case. Family notified.

Biopsy (31625) bundled into destruction (31641) at same site.

global_comments: Patient death intraoperatively; bill for all procedures fully completed prior to or during resuscitation.
Chest tubes and CPR are critical care/emergency procedures distinct from the bronchoscopy.
Modifiers XE/XS (or 59) used for chest tubes to indicate distinct encounters/sites relative to the bronchoscopy.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant lung mass with left lower lobe and partial left main-stem obstruction
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant airway obstruction 
INDICATIONS: left mainstem obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the T180 therapeutic video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Right sided bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; there are no endobronchial lesions, and no secretions.  The proximal and mid left mainstem were normal. In the distal left mainstem a white fungating tumor was seen causing complete obstruction of the left lower lobe and extending from the left lower lobe bronchus to causing complete obstruction of the lingula and 80% obstruction of the left mainstem.  The LMA was then removed and a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the mid trachea and attached to the jet ventilator. The rigid optic was then removed and the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope. We then utilized cryoextraction to remove large pieces of tumor piece meal. Most of the superficial tumor was avascular and did not bleed but as we continued debulking into less necrotic tumor mild bleeding occurred and was treated with cold saline flushes. After extensive debulking we were able to advance the bronchoscope into the lingula were some purulent secretions were seen and performed mini BAL. The tumor however extended into the subsegments of the lingula and deemed likely not salvageable with endobronchial treatment alone.  APC was then used to coagulate the residual superficial layer of oozing tumor. At the end of the procedure distal left mainstem was only 15% obstructed. The left upper lobe proper (anterior and apical posterior segments) were completely patent. The lingula was 80% obstructed and the left lower lobe remained completely obstructed with distal tumor. Once we were satisfied that there was no active bleeding the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Recommendations:
Transfer to PACU and then home once discharge criteria met. 
Will discuss with oncology if biopsy samples obtained during procedure need any specific mutational analysis. 
Defer to oncology regarding medical and radiation treatment. 
Will monitor for symptoms or radiographic signs of tumor regrowth and possible need for repeat debulking to salvage left upper lobe.

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Malignant lung mass with left lower lobe and partial left main-stem obstruction

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Right side normal. Proximal/mid LMS normal. Distal LMS fungating tumor causing complete obstruction of LLL and lingula, 80% LMS obstruction.

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Monitor for symptoms or radiographic signs of tumor regrowth

cao_interventions_detail.notes: Tumor extended into subsegments of lingula; LLL remained obstructed.

per_code.summary: Supported by documentation of APC coagulation and cryoextraction for tumor destruction in the distal left mainstem. Selected over 31640 as dominant modality for same-site lesion.

documentation_evidence.snippet: APC was then used to coagulate the residual superficial layer... cryoextraction to remove large pieces

rules_applied.details: 31641 kept as primary; 31640 dropped for same anatomic site.

global_comments: Rigid bronchoscopy (no specific CPT, usually 31622 foundation or bundled) facilitates the therapeutic interventions.
General anesthesia was used; do not bill moderate sedation.

metadata.notes: Procedure performed in OR with rigid bronchoscopy and jet ventilation.

note_text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Respiratory failure secondary extrinsic tracheal compression
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: extrinsic tracheal compression s/p airway stent placement
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy, Silicone Y-stent placement
INDICATIONS: Severe extrinsic tracheal compression
Consent was obtained from the patient’s family prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. The patient was sedated in the upright position and once anesthesia was comfortable that she could be ventilated, muscle relaxation was given and the patient was laid flat. A 14mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the upper trachea and advanced past the near complete mid-tracheal extrinsic compression and connected to the Jet ventilator while in the distal trachea.  The T190 Olympus flexible bronchoscope was then introduced through the rigid bronchoscope and into the airways. The distal trachea was approximately 60% obstructed extrinsically. The proximal 2/3 of the left mainstem were extrinsically compressed by about 50%. The distal left mainstem and left sided airways were normal the right mainstem and distal airways appeared normal without compression, mucosal changes or endobronchial disease.  After measuring the airways we customized a 14x10x10 silicone Y-stent to a length of 90mm in the tracheal limb, 16mm in the right mainstem limb and 33mm in the left mainstem limb. The rigid bronchoscope was then advanced into the left mainstem and the stent was deployed. After deployment, the rigid forceps were used to manipulate the stent to adequately position the limbs within the proper airways resulting in successful stabilization of the airway. During this short period patient was difficult to ventilate and oxygen desaturation occurred. The rigid bronchoscope was removed and an LMA was inserted. She was easily ventilated and oxygen saturation quickly returned to normal. The flexible bronchoscope was then inserted through the LMA for re-inspection. The Stent was well seated with the proximal limb approximately 2 cm distal to the vocal cords. The mid-stent was compressed by the extrinsic force of the mediastinal mass to 60% of normal. The left mainstem and right mainstem were widely patent. The bronchoscope was subsequently removed and the procedure completed. 
Recommendations:
- Transfer back  to ICU
- Obtain post procedure CXR
- TID hypertonic nebulizers with albuterol (3cc 3% and 2cc albuterol) to avoid mucous impaction and obstruction of stent
- Ensure supplemental oxygen is humidified
- Discuss with IR for biopsy
- Please arrange for patient to have nebulizer at home for continued hypertonic saline nebs post-discharge.
- If invasive ventilatory support is required blind intubation (direct laryngoscopy, glidescope) should be avoided as it can result in dislodgment of the tracheal stent and potential catastrophic airway obstruction.  Intubation should be performed with a 6.5 or smaller ETT with bronchoscopic insertion to visualize the distal tip of the endotracheal tube. The endotracheal tube should be advanced approximately 3 cm into the tracheal limb of the stent and secured.	
- Extubation must be performed with flexible bronchoscope to allow visualization of the stent and using flexible forceps to apply downward pressure on the main carina while retracting the ETT to avoid dislodging of the stent.

diagnostic_bronchoscopy.inspection_findings: Distal trachea 60% obstructed extrinsically. Proximal 2/3 of left mainstem 50% compressed. Right mainstem normal.

complications.other_complication_details: Difficult ventilation and oxygen desaturation during stent manipulation; resolved with LMA insertion

outcomes.follow_up_plan_text: Transfer to ICU, post-procedure CXR, nebulizers to prevent plugging

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of tracheal stent(s)

lines.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
lines.selection_reason: Primary therapeutic procedure: placement of Y-stent covering trachea and carina. Under NCCI and CPT rules, 31631 describes placement of tracheal/carinal stents and bundles minor extensions into main bronchi.

note_spans.snippet: customized a 14x10x10 silicone Y-stent to a length of 90mm in the tracheal limb

lines.selection_reason: Bundled into surgical bronchoscopy (31631) performed in the same session.

note_spans.snippet: T190 Olympus flexible bronchoscope was then introduced

financial_analysis.mppr_assumptions: Single therapeutic endoscopy billed; no MPPR reduction applied.
financial_analysis.notes: Values are 2025 Medicare national averages, unadjusted for geography.

per_code.summary: Selected for Y-stent placement. The stent spans the trachea and mainstem bronchi. CPT 31631 covers tracheal/carinal stents. While the stent extends into the bronchi, 31631 is the most comprehensive single code for a Y-stent involving the trachea. NCCI typically bundles 31636 (bronchial stent) if performed via the same deployment for a contiguous Y-stent, or payer policy may prefer 31636 + 31637 if extensions are significant, but standard practice for a single Y-stent device involving the trachea is 31631.

documentation_evidence.snippet: customized a 14x10x10 silicone Y-stent to a length of 90mm in the tracheal limb

rules_applied.description: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled when more extensive therapeutic or biopsy bronchoscopy procedures from the same family are performed by the same physician on the same date of service.
Fluoroscopic guidance is included in bronchoscopy codes and should not be separately reported.
rules_applied.details: No fluoroscopy code was explicitly requested, but rule confirms exclusion.

global_comments: Patient underwent rigid bronchoscopy with placement of a silicone Y-stent for extrinsic tracheal and left mainstem compression.
CPT 31631 is selected for the Y-stent placement as it involves the trachea and carina.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled into the therapeutic intervention.
General anesthesia was used; moderate sedation codes (99152/99153) are not applicable.

metadata.notes: Complex airway case requiring rigid bronchoscopy and Y-stent. Significant extrinsic compression managed successfully.
